page.title: 02THE ALTAR, WISBOROUGH GREEN
page.content: This church was built in the eleventh century but was added to in 1867. In the church there is an altar. The top stone is of the same stone as Stone henge and is probably 4,000 years old. When Edward VI was king he ordered all stone altars and stone statues to be smashed, but some men came from Lox wood and told Wisborough Green that the soldiers were coming. The locals took down the stone and hid the bottom part under a bridge in Holy Water Lane and they built the other part into Loxwood Vicarage chimney. In the nineteenth century when the bridge was being repaired the stone was found and when they pulled down Loxwood Vicarage they found the top stone. It was used as a garden seat until 1937 when both stones were ret- urned to St. Peter's Church.
